text: Example

Iâ€™ll be using one of the public datasets available in BigQuery so you can recreate this yourself. It is the â€˜Iowa Liquor Salesâ€™ dataset (`bigquery-public-data.iowa_liquor_sales.sales`) which has the daily liquor sales in Iowa going back to 2012.

The liquor sales are broken out a bunch of different ways including city, county, lat/long, category, bottles sold, volume sold etc. For this example Iâ€™m just going to be looking at total sales by day but you can detect anomalies in any of the breakouts in the table.
The full query with comments can be found on my GitHub page and here is a gist. Letâ€™s break down what the query does.

The first thing I do is create a CTE (common table expression) to make a table with the 25th percentile, the 75th percentile and the IQR for the total liquor sales by day to use in the main part of the query.

To get the quartiles Iâ€™m using BigQueryâ€™s approximate quantile function. Weâ€™re saying we want 4 quantiles which creates an array, so we just select which quantile we want out of that array with the offset function.

The array returned looks like this [min, 25, 50, 75, max]. As you can see it also returns the min and max values. Indexing starts at zero so it would be [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]. So for the 25th percentile we select the element at position 1 and so on using the offset function.
Next we move on to the main part of the query:

Starting at the inner query, weâ€™re going to grab the total liquor sales by day again, then cross join with the IQR CTE we created above (beware of cross joins on large datasets though). Then weâ€™re going to create a case statement for if that dayâ€™s liquor sales are positive/negative outliers or not (inlier). For display purposes we also grab the dayâ€™s total sales and date and order by total daily sales descending. Which gives us:
We now have a column called â€˜typeâ€™ which will tell us whether the dayâ€™s liquor sales are an inlier, a positive outlier or a negative outlier.

Letâ€™s take a look at the distribution of the data to confirm the query worked. Here is a histogram which shows a bunch of dayâ€™s with almost no sales at all on the left and some days with really high sales on the right. Both of which should be investigated further.
Here is a boxplot showing the outliers. You can see that the boxplot mirrors the query with the positive outliers being identified around $2.1MM like we saw in the output above.

Now you can schedule this query to run everyday (or as frequently as you need it) and output into a table. You then have a table, updated automatically that identifies outliers which you can connect to youâ€™re visualization tool of choice.

You can also take this a step further and run this in a cloud function/lambda and automatically send slack alerts/emails through the api when anomalies are detected with some basic info about the anomaly. I automated slack alerts for anomalies at work this way and it has gone over really well. Iâ€™ll write a post about that in the future.

Something like this is really easy to get up and running in a short amount of time by anyone who can use SQL (analysts, data scientists, engineers etc.) and is also very effective. Now you can get back to youâ€™re machine/deep learning ğŸ˜ƒ
Anomaly Detection With SQL

There are many ways to detect anomalies in data and like most things in life, not really a clear and cut â€˜right wayâ€™ it to do it. The approach you take will be dictated by your data but also the requirements of the project.

Is this something that needs to be as accurate as possible like credit fraud detection, do you just need to monitor some metrics for potential issues, does this need to be up and running fast or do you have 6 months to get it into production, what kind of resources do you have available to you etc.

Thereâ€™s two basic approaches to anomaly detection. You can go the rule based route or you can go the machine learning route. Machine learning models like Isolation forests, local outlier factor, autoencoders etc. can all be used to successfully detect anomalies. If youâ€™re going that route, you should check out sklearnâ€™s packages as well as the book Hands on Unsupervised Learning as good starting places.

text: However, rule based methods work well, are easier to implement, easier to put into production and faster to get up and running. Based on your requirements, they may be the best solution.

Look I get it, everyone wants to immediately go to machine/deep learning to solve problems because letâ€™s face it, itâ€™s fun and challenging. However, going the machine learning route isnâ€™t always the best option, especially in a business environment.

One rule based method that works well and is easy to implement in SQL is to use the interquartile range. The IQR is defined as the difference between the 75% percentile and the 25% percentile of your dataset.
If a data point is above the 75th percentile by 1.5x the IQR or more or below the 25th percentile by 1.5x the IQR or less, they can be considered outliers.

Why 1.5x and not 2x or 3x? 1.5x is pretty similar to 3 standard deviations above the mean (see the diagram below). You can certainly change it to 1.75x or 2.25x etc. depending on how â€˜sensitiveâ€™ you want the outlier detection to be, which is another great thing about using the IQR.

Since the IQR uses the median instead of the average itâ€™s considered a robust measure of scale and less likely to be influenced by a few outliers compared to measures that use the average such as standard deviation. This will make it easier to identify actual outliers.

If youâ€™ve ever seen a boxplot, thatâ€™s just the IQR method of outlier detection visualized. The â€˜boxâ€™ is the IQR, the â€˜whiskersâ€™ are at the 25th and 75th percentile and any data points above those (called â€˜fliersâ€™) are the outliers as you can see from the below diagram:

A couple more notes about anomaly detection before we get to the example. Anomaly detection can be univariate or multivariate. Univariate is much simpler and easier to interpret since you can know easily which metric triggered the anomaly. If you have multiple metrics then you can just set up separate queries to detect anomalies for each metric which makes the end product much more interpretable. If youâ€™re going the multivariate route, machine learning may be better suited for that. Anomaly detection can also be either supervised or unsupervised but the majority of the time it is unsupervised like weâ€™re doing here.
